provenance.note: According to Keynes this letter has the same history as another Blake to Butts letter (21 September 1800). Acquired from Captain Butts about 1906 by the late W. Graham Robertson and bequeathed by him to his executor, Mr. Kerrison Preston, who gave it with his Blake collection to the City of Westminster Central Reference Library in 1967. Since that time, the Westminster Central Reference Library has been incorporated into the City of Westminster Archives Centre.

desc.objtitle: After I had finished my letter I found, Object 1

objnote.p: A single leaf, written on two sides, the other half missing.

This object is divided into a prose paragraph filling roughly half the leaf and two columns of verse which fill up the botton half. There are two hand-drawn (non-ruled) lines on the leaf. One is a horizontal line separating the prose paragraph from the verse columns and the other is a broken line between running vertically between the two verse columns. There are two lines of verse written vertically, running up the left hand side of the paper, with an X indicating where Blake intended them to be inserted in the verse stanza (according to his note above those lines). The outer edges of this paper are a different color from the rest of it (the part the writing is on) but it is difficult to tell why. The date of the letter and the number "8" are inscribed at the top of the first object in an unknown hand.

lg.l: Dear Sir
After I had finishdfinished my Letter I found that I had
not said half what I intended to say & in particular I
wish to ask you what Subject you choose to be painted onErdman (page 720) reads "Subject" as "subject".
the remaining Canvas which I brought down with me (for
there were three) and to tell you that several of the
Drawings were in great forwardness you will see by the
Inclosedenclosed Account that the remaining Number of Drawings which you gave
me orders for is Eighteen I will finish them with all possible Expedition
if indeed I have not tired you or as it is politely calldcalled Bored you
too much already or if you would rather cry out Enough Off Off!
tell me in a Letter of forgiveness if you were offended & of accustomdaccustomed
friendship if you were not. But I will bore you more with some
Verses which My Wife desires me to Copy out & send you with her
kind love & Respect they were Composed ^ a twelvemonth ago in
a Walking from FelFelphampham to Lavant to meet my SisterThere is a non-ruled line drawn beneath these words separating the prose paragraph from the verse stanzas beneath it
With happiness stretchdstretched across the hills
In a cloud that dewy sweetness distills
With a blue sky spread over with wings
And a mild sun that mounts & sings
With trees & fields full of Fairy elves
And little devils who fight for themselves
Remembering the Verses that Hayley sung
When my heart knockdknocked against the root of my tongue
lg.note: Lines 22 and 23 are written vertically along the left margin. The word "Remembering" is written above line 24. Blake also writes "These 2 lines were omitted in transcribing & ought to come in at X"
lg.l: With Angels planted in Hawthorn bowers
And God himself in the passing hours
With Silver Angels across my way
And Golden Demons that none can stay
With my Father hovering upon the wind
And my Brother Robert just behind
And my Brother John the evil one
In a black cloud making his monemoan
ThoThough dead they appear upon my path
Notwithstanding my terrible wrath
They beg they intreatentreat they drop their tears
Filldfilled full of hopes filldfilled full of fears
With a thousand Angels upon the Wind
Pouring disconsolate from behind
To drive them off & before my way
A frowning Thistle implores my stay
What to others a trifle appears
Fills me full of smiles or tears
For double the vision my Eyes do see
And a double vision is always with me
With my inward Eye 'tis an old Man greygray
With my outward a Thistle across my way
"If thou goest back the thistle said
Thou art to endless woe betraydbetrayed
For here does Theotormon lower
And here is Enitharmons bower
And Los the terrible thus hath sworn
Because thou backward dost return
Poverty

objnote.p: A single leaf, written on two sides, the other half missing.

This leaf contains two columns of verse that take up most of the upper three quarters of the page and a short prose paragraph at the bottom concluding the letter. There are three hand-drawn (non-ruled) lines on the leaf. One is a broken vertical line between the two columns of verse. Another is a horizontal line at the bottom of the right hand column, the shorter of the two. The third is directly above the prose paragraph at the bottom of the leaf separating it from the columns of verse above it. The creases in the leaf are noteworthy, seeming to indicate that it was folded into quarters at one point, as is the final PS line, the text of which is transcribed vertically up the right hand edge of the leaf.

lg.l: Poverty Envy old age & fear
Shall bring thy Wife upon a bier
And Butts shall give what Fuseli gave
"A dark black Rock & a gloomy Cave"
I struck the Thistle with my foot
And broke him up from his delving root
"Must the duties of life each other cross"
"Must every joy be dung & dross"
"Must my dear Butts feel cold neglect"
"Because I give Hayley his due respect"
"Must Flaxman look upon me as wild"
"And all my friends be with doubts beguildbeguiled"
"Must my Wife live in my Sisters bane
"Or my Sister survive on my Loves pain
"The curses of Los the terrible shade"
"And his dismal terrors make me afraid"
So I spoke & struck in my wrath
The old man weltering upon my path.
Then Los appeardappeared in all his power
In the sun he appeardappeared descending before
My face in fierce flames in my double sight
Twas outward a Sun: inward Los in his might
"My hands are labourdlaboured day & night"
"And Ease comes never in my sight"
"My Wife has no indulgence given"
"Except what comes to her from heaven"
"We eat little we drink less "
"This Earth breeds not our happiness"
"Another Sun feeds our lifes streams"
We
"We are not warmed with thy beams"
"Thou measurest not the Time to me"
Nor yet the Space that I do see "
My Mind is not with thy light arraydarrayed"
Thy terrors shall not make me afraid"
When I had my Defiance given
The Sun stood trembling in heavenBentley (*Writings*, page 1565) reads "The" as "Tho".
The Moon that glowdglowed remote below
Became leprous & white as snow
And every Soul of men on the Earth
Felt affliction & sorrow & sickness & dearth
Los flamdflamed in my path & the Sun was hot
With the bows of my Mind & the Arrows of Thought
My bowstring fierce with ArdourArdor breathesBentley (*Writings*, page 1566) reads "bowstring" as "bow string."
My arrows glow in their golden sheaves
My brothers & father march before
The heavens drop with human gore
Now I a fourfold vision see
And a fourfold vision is given to me
Tis fourfold in my supreme delight
And three fold in soft Beulahs night
And twofold Always. May God us keep
From Single vision & Newtons sleepsleepThere is a non-ruled line at the bottom of this verse stanza separating it from the blank space beneath it
I also incloseenclose you some Ballads by MrMr Hayley with prints to them by Your
Hble.HumbleServt.Servant I should have sent them before now but could not get any thinganything
done for You to please myself for I do assure you that I have truly studied
the two little pictures I now send & do not repent of the time I have spent

God bless you
Yours WBWilliam Blake

P.S. I have taken the liberty to trouble you with a letter to my Brother which you will be so kind as to send or give him & oblige yours WBThe text is inscribed vertically beginning with the "d" in "kind."
